abstract: A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airline’s earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate. The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion). At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed. “The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny,” said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.

lead_paragraph: A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airline’s earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate. The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion). At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed. “The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny,” said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.
